channel.title: Deployment on Baywet's blog
channel.description: Recent content in Deployment on Baywet's blog

item.title: Deploying cloud service via new 2015 build templates
item.author: vbiret+blog@outlook.com (Vincent Biret)
item.description: Introduction to the new build system Microsoft recently made a new build definitions model with the release of Visual Studio 2015 (TFS 2015’s bits are not yet available but this new build service is already available on Visual Studio Online). Just as a reminder the “old” build models were based on two artifacts: The build process template: defined via XAML, it allows you to configure the sequence for the build process.

item.title: Repackaging of SharePoint 2010 language packs
item.author: vbiret+blog@outlook.com (Vincent Biret)
item.description: SharePoint 2010 service pack 2 came out a few months ago from now. It brings lot of new things, I’ll blog about that in further posts. One of these new things is the repackaging of language packs. Indeed you may have missed it but it is not required anymore to do a progressive installation in order to support MUI in SharePoint 2010 when setting up a new farm. Before, when one wanted to install language packs (let’s take for example French English and Spanish), one had to:

item.title: Managing Resources, how to make your SharePoint solutions “globally deployed”
item.author: vbiret+blog@outlook.com (Vincent Biret)
item.description: Introduction I wanted to publish this article months ago, back to the time I found this solution. But I did not mostly because of a lack of free time. Sebastien LEVERT, a top SharePoint developer and a member of Montreal’s SharePoint community, recently published a post about the same subject. Read it (sorry it’s in French), I’ll write my post so it is complementary. https://www.pimpmysharepoint.com/2014/01/09/deployer-des-fichiers-de-ressources-simplement/ Reminders To quickly summarize, when you develop SharePoint solutions and you want to support multiple languages (localize it) you need to use .
